title-group.article-title: A modularized contact-rule reasoning approach to the assembly sequence generation for product design

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Creative Product Design, College of Arts, Nanhua University, Chiayi, Taiwan
3Department of Product Design, Transworld University, Douliou, Taiwan
4Department of Industrial Design, College of Planning and Design, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Ming-Chyuan Lin, Department of Creative Product Design, College of Arts, Nanhua University, No. 55, Sec. 1, Nanhua Road, Dalin Township, Chiayi 622, Taiwan. Email: minglin@mail.nhu.edu.tw

abstract.p: Concurrent engineering design is widely used to shorten the time needed to introduce a new product and to enhance the quality of the design of the product. However, designers seldom consider the difficulty of assembling a product’s components and modules in the concurrent development process. In fact, the concept of design for assembly is not new. Planning the execution of assembly operations and selecting the assembly sequence during product development will provide designers with interrelated information of design and manufacture that help reduce manufacturing problems. The designer should realize that a reasonable assembly sequence for a product has a significant effect on the efficiency of the entire assembly process. This research focuses on the enhancement of the contact relation matrix approach to the generation of assembly sequences in a product design procedure. A systematic and efficient assembly sequence assistance procedure is proposed to generate feasible assembly sequences and to find an optimal sequence to assemble the product. Compared to the complexity of other methods, this research proposes a modularized contact-rule reasoning approach to generating assembly sequences. The general approach of this research is to (a) develop a modular method for assembly sequence planning, (b) use matrix operations to facilitate the generation of assembly sequences, and (c) generate the assembly sequence of the designed product by searching for subassembly extraction rules. The assembly sequences are then created in the form of a hierarchical structure. The results will assist designers to consider and reduce some manufacture problems in advance that might occur in the process of generation of the recommended design alternative.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Due to significant improvements in manufacturing technology and computer performance, the designer has a greater opportunity to consider both customer requirements and manufacturer concerns. Chen et al. (2002) proposed a laddering technique and Kohonen association in the Web system of customer-oriented product concept formation. Lin et al. (2006) presented a novel procedure to effectively link customer requirements with design characteristics in the product design process. Li et al. (2008) further introduced an adaptive design technique to generate product design alternatives that can be changed to satisfy different customer requirements. In general, the most common problem in design is the difficulty in communication between the design and production teams. Concurrent engineering (CE) is the most commonly used method to help reduce the communication gap (Prasad, 1996, 1997). The concept of design for assembly (DFA) is a subset of CE that is considered important because assembly is often a major contributor to manufacturing costs (Prasad, 1996). In the early stage of design, when analyzing feasible assembly sequences, it is necessary to reach a compromise between design concepts, configurations, and functions to facilitate the manufacture of the design (Prasad, 1996, 1997). However, the computational complexity of generating an efficient assembly sequence and a lack of understanding of the attributes of a quality assembly sequence has contributed to the lack of industry interest in sequence generation systems (Bekey, 1991). Consequently, designers often neglect to consider assembly in the design process.

Boothroyd and Dewhurst (1991) analyzed and summarized assembly rules by evaluating relative movement and contact relations to consider assembly feasibility during the design process. The method has been applied practically to both manual and robotic assembly processes. Kroll et al. (1989) and Pu (1992) presented a problem-solving paradigm, or case-based reasoning (CBR), to solve physical constraint-oriented design problems. Using the proposed rules of CBR, a designer can find similar characteristics to leverage and assist assembly sequence planning. Dini and Santochi (1992) used adjacency matrices to represent product assembly for reverse assembly planning. Three matrices, the interference matrix, contact matrix, and connection matrix, were located on a Cartesian coordinate system to build a detailed part relationship and assembly sequence. Tonshoff (1992) suggested that the data created from task-related, object-related, and organization rules could be transferred to assembly information and used for sequence planning. Lee and Shin (1993) assigned part details to nodes and established merge rules, such that the relations between the details and attributes of liaison graphs could be formed based on the rules. However, the method could be costly and time-consuming when applied to a large number of detailed components.

It should be noted that the number of feasible assemblies will increase exponentially with the number of parts. Not only is it complicated and difficult to judge the relations between parts, but it is also an error-prone and time-consuming process. Improving efficiency and finding feasible assembly sequences are becoming increasingly important in design practice. It has been suggested that designers should use modularized relations to determine which details can be assembled together as a subassembly. Liao et al. (1995) used the bill of material (BOM) as a basic input to modules and considered both geometric and technical constraints in planning. He presented a computer-aided planning system and showed that the proposed approach could be used for planning assemblies as large as an aircraft frame. Yee and Ventura (1999) created an assembly operation that constrains rules and is represented by a Petri net model. He converted an AND/OR graph into a 0/1-integer linear program to minimize the total assembly time and cost and satisfy three constraint rules. Wang and Kim (1999) presented a feature-based method to obtain assembly mating relations between a set of polyhedral components. Feature representations of components were used to identify mating relations between the components. The feature of components was decomposed to generate an assembly mating algorithm. Using the assembly configuration mating algorithm and backtracking search, the feasible assembly configurations were generated. Siddique and Rosen (2001) introduced design spaces that modeled physical connectivity, function, and assembly for a representative product family. The article demonstrated how to define constraints and apply them to the design spaces, so that feasible design regions could be considered for modularization. Zhang et al. (2002) proposed that an automobile body could be described through two matrices representing precedence among components. The proposed method describes a procedure to derive feasible assembly sequences automatically for automobile body assembly. However, increasing the number of components causes difficulty in the assembly planning process because the order of the two matrices is not easy to control with this method. Gottipolu and Ghosh (2003) established an approach to verify the feasibility of assembly. Connectivity and precedence constraints are converted to contact and translation functions, and the feasibility of contact and disassembly is determined for each component.

Yin et al. (2003) modified the connector-based structure (CBS) hierarchical approach that emphasizes the possibilities of movement and assembly to rapidly construct feasible and realistic sequences. To enable this modification, the connector-based relational model (CBRM) was proposed to support the identification of CBSs. Chen et al. (2004) exploited a three-stage integrated approach to develop a graph and transforming rules that were used to create a graph model and incidence matrix, which were employed together with a formulated penalty index to generate a feasible sequence. However, as the number of components is increased, the increasing index is weighted according to the difficulty caused by the complexity. Barnes et al. (2004) presented a method for product design and assembly sequence generation in which feasibility and practicality are considered simultaneously. The proposed constraints are based on two stages of decision support. In the first stage, structure definition, parts are created and combined into subassemblies; in the second stage, sequence generation decisions are made. Barnes’ research has developed the structure of a mating joint hierarchy for product assembly; however, it is limited to handling mating constraints. Chan et al. (2006) then introduced a framework of a web-based three-dimensional (3D) assembly system to help customers make their design decision. Lin et al. (2007) developed the contact relation matrix (CRM) approach, which is based on four rules identified from part contact relations and uses a matrix representation to recommend a design alternative. However, the number of components is too large to be applied easily. To fix this difficulty, Chang et al. (2009) proposed an artificial immune system to solve product assemblies with many assembly constraints. However, the method must avoid the tendency of falling into local solutions. Giudice et al. (2009) also presented an integrated approach that combine finite element analysis (FEA) tools with design for manufacture and assembly (DFMA) to improve the design solutions for ease of production. Chen et al. (2010) then generated an explosion graph and constructed an incidence matrix for validating assembly relations. Heuristic working rules were proposed to assist the planner in obtaining an assembly plan, and the Taguchi method was incorporated to generate a data set for neural network training to create the assembly model (Chen et al., 2010). Reddy and Siddique (2010) proposed a mathematical method to generate feasible assembly sequences and select an assembly process that helps to reduce the existing modification cost. However, the variety of products in the marketplace and the differences between them still challenge the designer. Because modular design eases the sharing of design information and reduces aftermarket costs, this article proposes an approach that considers modular design to reduce the difficulties that the CRM approach has with large numbers of components and constraints. It is shown that the modularized contact-rule reasoning (MCRR) approach proposed in this article can assist designers in simplifying assembly alternatives by evaluating the relations within each module in an efficient way to avoid the need for complex algorithms and calculation.

This article is organized as follows. Section “A framework for the development of the MCRR approach” provides a conceptual model of the MCRR method. In section “Case study,” the proposed approach is applied to a case study of a coffeemaker and used to generate the assembly sequences of a bicycle. Conclusions are presented in section “Conclusions.”

sec.title: A framework for the development of the MCRR approach
sec.p: In this research, a procedure for subassembly extraction rules is developed, and a contact-rule reasoning approach is introduced, which is applied from the module level to the full assembly to generate feasible assembly sequences. During the assembly sequence reasoning process, contact relations, functional information, and geometric relations are reviewed, and modularized reasoning rules and contact rules are applied. The basic definition and reasoning processes are explained in this section.

sec.title: Definition of contact rules
sec.p: Let T be a product design database comprising the set of (Pi,Vi,j). Pi is the design output recommendation that describes a feasible design option, and Vi,j is its value. The index i=1,2,…,n, where n is the number of design components, and j=1,2,…,m, where m is the number of alternative options for each design component. T can be expressed as (Lin and Chen, 2005)

M
PL
is defined as a matrix that specifies an assembly alternative with a series of selected design output recommendations Pi. There are four rules that can be used to generate the contact relations between components and to identify assembly sequences for each alternative value (Lin et al., 2007).

list-item.p: Rule 1: If a design output recommendation Pa can be assembled independently of a design recommendation Pb, b≠a, then the assembly of these two design values should be performed before dependent design recommendations are assembled. If the design recommendation Pa can also be assembled independently of design recommendation Pc, c≠a, then one alternative should be chosen arbitrarily as the first in the assembly sequence.

Rule 2: If a design output recommendation Pa can be assembled with a design recommendation Pb, b≠a only when Pb has been assembled with a design recommendation Pc, c≠b, then the assembly of the two design values Pa and Pb should occur after Pb and Pc have been assembled.

Rule 3: If a design output recommendation Pa satisfies the conditions of Rule 2 and will be assembled with a design output recommendation Pb, b≠a, then the assembly of Pa and Pb should occur after the assembly of Pa is complete. Similarly, if Pa will be assembled with a Pb, b≠a, that satisfies Rule 2, then the assembly of Pa and Pb should occur after the assembly of Pb is complete.

Rule 4: If a design output recommendation Pa is assembled with three or more design output recommendations, for example, Pb, Pc, and Pd, b≠c≠d, simultaneously, then the assembly of this design value should occur after the three recommendations have been assembled. However, although the study of assembly operations is helpful in identifying this type of assembly sequence, this kind of assembly is not an efficient design and should be minimized or improved by redesign. Using reasoning based on contact relations, if a design output recommendation Pa is to be assembled with a design output recommendation Pb and either of them follows Rule 3, then Rule 4 is also applied.

sec.title: Development of subassembly extraction rules for MCRR
sec.p: To increase enterprise competitiveness and meet market requirements, global sourcing has become necessary, especially for complex products. Therefore, it is increasingly important for design teams to act in a unified manner to meet market growth and keep costs down. The effort necessary to create a large assembly grows as the number of components increases. However, the design process can be simplified by examining the structural and functional relations within each module of the assembly. Thus, subassembly extraction rules are incorporated into the proposed MCRR approach to improve the assembly process. In practice, when producing a complex product or modularized design, the designer must consider not only structure, form, and function but also dimensions and materials. It is possible to reduce the complexity of the assembly planning process by separating the procedure into modules. The assembly sequence is first reviewed and modified using subassembly extraction rules. The relations between components and modules are evaluated by contact rules. By this process, assembly cost and time can be reduced significantly, even when a large quantity of components is used, as in an automobile or aircraft.

The MCRR processes developed for the identification of assembly sequences for each alternative component are shown in Figure 1. Note that the contents of solid boxes in Figure 1 denote the major MCRR procedure. In the component design strategy, the designer takes into account the user requirements and the design characteristics to generate a design alternative that consists of several components (Lin and Chen, 2005). The subassembly extraction method is proposed by introducing three extraction rules based on satellite nodes, closed-loop connectors, and the stable support of structures to reduce complexity and to support assembly generation.

caption.p: Development framework for MCRR assembly assistance procedures.

sec.p: In the MCRR method, each component in the product is represented as a node. Define DORa,b(La;Pa|Pb,ra,b),∀Pa,Pb∈Pi, as the design output relation between Pa and Pb. The cell value VDORa,b is defined as VDORa,b=La×ra,b. La is the liaison of Pa to Pb. If there is no contact relation between Pa and Pb, then La=0 and ra,b=0. If La=1, then ra,b=1,2,3,or4 is one of the contact rules defined in the previous section.

When the contact relation between design output recommendations Pa and Pb is evaluated, if DORa,b=DORa,b(0;Pa|Pb,0) and VDORa,b=0, then Pa and Pb are considered independent, and there is no contact relation between Pa and Pb. In addition to the contact relation rules previously defined, three additional rules are introduced to define the relations between pairs of nodes for which VDORa,b≠0.

list-item.p: Satellite node: If a part has only one liaison with another master part and the liaison between them cannot be broken, then they can be assembled as a pair and become a single node. This part is defined as a satellite of the master part, and the equation is expressed as

where a,b∈n and (a,b) is one and only one pair node. If node Pa satisfies this equation, then it is defined as a satellite of the master node Pb. If node Pa acts as a satellite of master node Pb, then the cell value VDORa,b of DORa,b(1;Pa|Pb,1) is 1.

Closed-loop connector: If three or more nodes connect in a sequence within a closed circle and the nodes are not separable from each other, then the circle is defined as a closed-loop subassembly. The closed connector can be defined by

VDO
R
i , i − 1
= VDO
R
i , i + 1
= 1
, where i∈n and i are designated a closed-loop sequential node and VDORi,a=0, where Pa≠Pi−1 and Pa≠Pi+1.

Stable support: If two or more nodes are used to provide functional or stable support to the base or main structure, then they can be merged into a single node. The resulting node is defined as a stable support.

sec.p: The three subassembly extraction rules are applied at the module level before the four basic contact rules are applied to the full assembly. This approach is beneficial for the designer collaborating concurrently with team members who may be in different locations.

After applying the three subassembly extraction rules and rearranging the components according to the relations between the nodes, the connection diagram must be further simplified. In the next section, the generation of assembly sequences will be explained in the matrix form.

sec.title: Generation of the assembly sequence matrix by the MCRR method
sec.p: The three steps necessary to generate the assembly sequence matrix are introduced in this section. Let MPL and M′PL be the part matrices before and after the MCRR approach is applied, respectively. The matrices are defined with a dimension of 1×n, where n is the number of components of the corresponding design alternative. The original MPL can be expressed as

list-item.p: Step 1: Develop a CRM MCR for the generated design alternative: A CRM MCR is created based on the contact rules. According to the four contact rules, each array entry of the MCR matrix is determined by checking the type of contact relation between two components. If there is a contact relation, the value of the array entry in the matrix will be the contact rule number, from 1 to 4, defining the relation. Otherwise, there is no contact relation, and the entry is zero. It should be noted that from the nature of the four predefined contact rules that design output recommendation values with a lower contact rule number will be assembled before those with higher numbers.
The MCR matrix is the set of contact relations between each pair of design output recommendation values. The matrix contains array entries ri,j and can be defined as

Step 2: Generate part matrix MPL and contact matrix MCT: Two matrices, the identity matrix MI and the contact matrix MCT, are introduced. The identity matrix MI is an n-dimensional square matrix whose diagonal entries are equal to 1. It is defined as
The contact matrix MCT is a constant matrix with entries equal to 1 wherever ri,j≠0 in MCR.

sec.p: If the array entry in the ith row and jth column of the MCR matrix is nonzero, the four contact rules are reviewed to determine whether the array entry satisfies the contact relation that currently has the highest priority. If the highest priority contact relation is satisfied, the array entry of MI at location (j,i) is assigned a value of 1, and the entry at (j,j) is assigned a value of 0 to form the new contact matrix M′CT. The current part matrix M′PL is then obtained by calculating the matrix product of the part matrix MPL and the new contact matrix M′CT.
These processes are formulated in equations (1) and (2) to demonstrate how the latest part assembly status is generated.
if ri,j≠0 in MCR, then

This step generates a new 1×n matrix M′PL that shows the most current part assembly status. Searching the array entries in MCR row by row, the assembly M′PL can be expressed as equation (2) and generated layer by layer with the product of matrix MPL and M′CT. This process can also be expressed in matrix form as follows
If array entry ri,j in MCR is nonzero, then M′CT can be expressed as

list-item.p: Step 3: Generate a part assembly sequence: Examine the array entries beginning with the first row of MCR. If an array entry in MCR equals the lowest integer in the current MCR, then place a 0 in the identified array element in MI and place the same integer in the transposed array element. After the matrix generation process in equations (1) and (2) is performed, the assembly status is given by M′PL, and the identity matrix MI is reset to its original status for the next operation. The process is repeated until all of the elements in the MCR matrix have been searched and checked. Detailed generation processes and an example will be illustrated in the next section.

sec.p: After the extraction rules are reviewed and the four contact rules are applied to determine the assembly sequence, the procedure follows the above three steps to generate the relevant matrices and assembly sequence. A detailed process with an example will be presented in the next section.

Figure 2 is a flow chart that shows step by step how the procedure generates assembly sequences. The approach follows the above three steps to generate the relevant matrices and assembly sequence. It should be noted that one assembly layer can be generated at a time by the matrix operation. This method will not cause interference problems during the assembly process because assembly violations were isolated, and relations were defined when the CRM was generated. If the sequence does not satisfy the designer, it can be randomly regenerated by another operation until the final requirements are achieved.

Recursively using the new contact matrix M′CT as it is modified by considering the contact relations in MCR, the new part matrix M′PL can be generated. By applying the generation rules and replacing sequences until all of array entries ra,b have been checked by the contact rules criteria and all elements in MCR are equal to zero, the assembly generation is completed.

A four-component example is illustrated to show how assembly sequences are generated. Assume four parts P01, P02, P03, and P04 will be assembled. The part matrix MPL=[P01P02P03P04] is a row matrix with the dimension of 1×4.

In the assembly sequence, P01 and P02 are assembled as one subassembly, and P03 and P04 are assembled as a second subassembly before all four parts are assembled together. The assembly relation matrix MCR, contact matrix MCT, and transform matrix MTL are represented as

According to the assembly sequence generation procedure, the lowest value of the array entries in MCR is r2,1=r1,2=1; thus, the components associated with these entries are the first to be assembled. The new contact matrix M′CT is generated by setting the array entries of MI at position (2,1) to 1 and position (2,2) to 0. The assembly operation is represented as the dot product of part matrix MPL and M′CT. The assembly process calculated in equation (3) shows that P01 and P02 are to be assembled together, as

After the first assembly process is completed, the next assembly entry is r4,3=r3,4=1. The same assembly procedure is followed, and the new part matrix is calculated as M′PL=[(P01+P02)0(P03+P04)0]. After the transformations of entry values equal to 1 are completed, entry r1,3=r3,1=2 is the next to be assembled. The array entries in MCR are changed as in equation (4) and the final assembly is calculated. The result shows that subassemblies P01+P02 and P03+P04 are assembled independently first, and (P01+P02) and (P03+P04) are assembled together next, which is denoted by ((P01+P02)+(P03+P04)).
After the operation is completed, every array entry in the CRM MCR is equal to 0 and the assembly generation process is completed.

sec.title: Case study
sec.p: To assist designers in handling assembly problems, this research proposes an approach that incorporates contact relations and the characteristics of design recommendation alternatives to integrate the design and assembly processes into a product design system. To validate the feasibility of adapting the proposed method to the product assembly sequence planning process, an Italian coffeemaker is selected as an example. Assume that a recommended design alternative is generated for a specific set of user requirements. The designer selects design output recommendations and their values from a design output database T. The design output recommendations and their values for this recommended design alternative are shown in Figure 3. The design choices for these components depend on the user’s requirements. Note that the assembly assistance procedures are also applicable to other product design applications as varied as bicycles, appliances, electronics, and office equipment. The recommended design alternative shown in Figure 3 is directly conducted by the contact relation matrix (CRM) for the generation of an assembly sequence as shown in Figure 4. In Figure 4, the coffeemaker has 29 components to be assembled. It appears that more complicated design alternatives with a large amount of components will make the generation of assembly sequences difficult to determine. The generation of the assembly sequence will then turn to the use of MCRR approach.

caption.p: The components of a coffeemaker selected as a design recommendation.
Generation of an assembly sequence for a coffeemaker based on CRM.

sec.title: Part relation preprocessing by subassembly extraction rules for MCRR
sec.p: The first procedure of the MCRR approach is to assign the parts to nodes and connect the parts with liaison lines based on their assembly relations. The connection diagram for the coffeemaker, with each component represented as a node, is shown in Figure 5(a). The graph can be simplified according to the following three subassembly extraction rules.

caption.p: Connection deployment and node reduction by subassembly extraction. (a) Initial liaison lines of the coffeemaker, (b) liaison lines after subassembly extraction, and (c) liaison line reduction result.

list-item.p: Satellite node review: When a node has only one relation with another master part and the liaison cannot be broken, the node can be treated as a satellite node of the master part. For example, DOR7,6(L7;P07|/P06,r7,6)=DOR7,6(1;P07|P06,1), VDOR7,6=1,andVDORi,j=0,i,j∉{6,7}. Node P07 has only one relation with node P06. Therefore, P07 is considered to be a satellite node of the P06 node, and P07 can be merged with P06 to form a new node B01. DOR8,10(L8;P08|P10,r8,10)=DOR8,10(1;P08|P10,1), VDOR8,10=1, and VDORi,j=0,i,j∉{8,10}. Node P08 is only connected to P10; thus, P08 is also a satellite node and can be merged with P10 to form a new node B02. After the relations between nodes are reviewed, there are 10 satellite nodes generated and denoted as B01, B02, …, B9 and B10 as shown in Figure 5(b). Note that B01 = (P07+P06), B02 = (P08+P10), B03 = (P16+P15), B04 = (P20+P21), B05 = (P22+P23), B06 = (P24+P25), B07 = (P26+P29), B08 = (P27+P28), B09 = ((P13+P12) +P14), and B10 = ((P17+P18) +P19).

Closed-loop connector review: If nodes are connected sequentially as a closed loop and cannot be separated from each other, the loop can be treated as a subassembly. For example, the relations between nodes B01 and P01, P02, P03, P05, and P04 can be expressed as
The relations between B01 and P01, P02, P03, P05, and P04 form a closed-loop connector. The nodes are merged to form a new node B11, which is formulated as
The relation matrix after these nodes are applied to the closed-loop connector is shown in Table 1.

Stable support review: The third step is to check for stable support relations within the node relations. For example, P09 is connected to P10 and P11 and fixes them in position. This relation satisfies the stable support condition, and the nodes can be merged to form a new node. P12 supports the assembly connected by P09, P10, and P11, and the assembly of P12 with P13 and P14 also satisfies the stable support rule. All of the nodes can be merged to form an assembly, which is labeled B12.

sec.p: When the three preprocessing steps are applied to the 29 components, 12 subassemblies, B01, B02, …, B12, are generated as shown in Figure 5(c). The application of subassembly extraction rules to simplify the generation of assembly sequences is described in the next section.

sec.title: Implementation of the contact relation approach
sec.p: To create the CRM MCR for the subset of design output identifiers B01, B02, …, B12, a matching procedure is employed to identify contact relations among Pi that directly relate to the design output recommendation values Pa or Ba. Each Pi value of the coffeemaker design recommendation is checked in the MCR matrix, from the first to the last row, to identify which rules are applicable for some specific design output recommendation values. The identification of the array entries of contact relations matrix MCR for the coffeemaker design case according to the four contact rules is illustrated in Table 2. Each array entry in MCR is examined to determine the assembly sequence for the corresponding Pi. If ri,j is equal to zero, then the array entry is skipped, and the searching index points to the next ri,j. If the value is not zero, then the algorithm will determine whether the contact relation will be assembled in this stage. A three-step search procedure beginning from the first row entries of MCR is described here.

list-item.p: Step 1: Develop a CRM MCR for the generated design alternative: Each array entry in MCR is assigned a value equal to the number of the relevant contact rule. The contact relations reviewed by the defined rules are illustrated in Table 2. According to the assembly development process, the four contact rules are used to identify an assembly sequence for each alternative value. Note that design output recommendation values with lower rule numbers will be assembled prior to those with higher numbers.

Step 2: Generate part matrix and transform matrices: The entries of the contact matrix MCT are created by assigning a value of 1 to the entries that are not equal to 0 in MCR. The corresponding matrix M′CT is generated by equation (2). Thus, the corresponding assembly arrangement M′PL is created. The entries with values equal to 1 in MCR are sequentially checked from the first row to the last in MCR.

sec.p: For example, in step 1, the array entry r3,4 in MCR is equal to 1. The relation created by r3,4 is the liaison between B05 and B06. According to the defined equation, M′CT is created from the identity matrix by setting r3,4 to 0, and array entries r4,3 and r4,4 are set to 1 and 0, respectively. The part matrix M′PL representing the latest assembly alternative is then identified by the dot product of matrices MPL and M′CT.

Figure 6 illustrates how the proposed process is used to form the first part assembly sequence matrix (PASM) M′PL, in which subassemblies B05 and B06 of the coffeemaker design have been assembled. The second array entry with a value of 1 is r5,9, which corresponds to B07 and B12. The M′CT matrix is created from the identity matrix by setting array entry r5,9 to 0 and entries r9,5 and r9,9 to 1 and 0, respectively. The second assembly sequence matrix M′PL represents that the assembly sequence after subassemblies B07 and B12 of the coffeemaker design have been assembled. As a result, the main container subassembly B12, which includes the main container, outer cover stand, cover, and switch, will be assembled to the filter and connector. After the matrix has been searched for array entries equal to 1, the search for entries equal to 2 is begun.

caption.p: Final result of a coffeemaker subassembly extraction with MCRR.

list-item.p: Step 3: Generate a part assembly sequence: The M′CT matrix is reset to its original status, and step 2 is repeated until all of the entries in the MCR matrix are reviewed and changed to zero. The assembly processes is completed, and one of the assembly sequences is generated. The first array entry equal to 2 is r2,3, followed by r5,7 and r6,8. There are three array entries equal to 1, three entries equal to 2, one equals to 3, and two equal to 4. The assembly contact relations are illustrated in Table 2.

sec.p: It should be noted that another feasible assembly sequence could be generated by rearranging the nodes. Most of the time, it is not necessary to apply the matrix calculation to most of the subassemblies because they have a limited number of parts after the subassembly extraction rules are reviewed. After subassemblies have been extracted, the MCRR approach is used to generate the final assembly sequence.

One of the feasible assemblies has been generated, and a result is achieved. If the result does not satisfy the designer’s requirements, it can be randomly regenerated by another operation until the requirements are achieved. The whole assembly sequence is generated by substituting all of the parameters of the original parts. Figure 7 shows the final result in a hierarchical structure.

caption.p: Generation of an assembly sequence for a coffeemaker based on MCRR.

sec.p: The sorting approach performances between CRM and MCRR are evaluated and illustrated in the Table 3. Due to the assembly sequencing is simulated by personal computer, the central processing unit (CPU) time is selected as evaluation factor for assembly efficiency. The assembly processes are followed to assembly procedure flow chart illustrated in Figure 2 and programmed by Visual Basic 6.0 to generate the assembly sequence alternative and to retrieve CPU time used in the program. In the Ruled Based Assembly Sequence Generation method, there are four matrices that the dimensions are the same as the number of designed components. The CRM matrix is defined by the contact relations between each component. The assembly priority matrix (APM), transitional part assembly sequence matrix (TPASM), and PASM are generated that followed the rules of the approach addressed in Lin et al. (2007). Since there are many feasible assembly procedure alternatives that can meet assembly requirements, the proposed assembly sequence will be evaluated and regenerated alternative, if necessary sequence modifications for the design are recommended. Compared with Ruled Based Assembly Sequence Generation method, the subassembly problems of MCRR approach are considered within each module by reviewing subassembly extraction rules in the design stages. The efficiency of the approach are proposed and defined by the time measured from program start to the end. The less CPU time used, the more efficiency is recognized. In the case study of coffeemaker assembly, the subassembly procedures are considered in the module design stages. Three loops of subassembly extraction rules are applied to examine the feasible subassembly assembly sequence. Through this rules review, the matrix dimension is reduced from 29 to 10, and the variation of the assembly alternative is reduced. Based on the time captured by the program, it shows that the MCRR method reduces the CPU time from 0.02 s used by Ruled Based Assembly Sequence Generation method to 0.011 s used by MCRR method. It is noted that the method can be introduced to larger component such as car and aircraft as they are all modularized designed. Also, the more components are considered, the more computation time and cost are saved.

caption.p: Comparison of CRM and MCRR approaches

fn.p: CRM: contact relation matrix; APM: assembly priority matrix; TPASM: transitional part assembly sequence matrix; PASM: part assembly sequence matrix.

sec.p: The same assembly procedure can be applied to the assembly of a bicycle. Assume a bicycle design alternative is recommended with components and modules as illustrated in Table 4. The number of components for the recommended bicycle design is 25. The assembly sequence based on CRM is generated in Figure 8. In Figure 8, the generated assembly sequence without considering the modular assembly concept looks quite complicated. Therefore, it is a product of bicycle that can be assembled by modules, including the frame, steering system, transmission system, saddle, tire and rim, brake system, and accessories as illustrated in Table 4. From the hierarchical assembly tree, it can be noted that the first module assembled is the frame. The front rim and tire are then tightly screwed to the fork of the frame. The three front gears are assembled to create the gear set and screwed to the frame along with the pedal cranks. The rear rim and tire are connected to the rear gear set, which is assembled from six gears. The front and rear brake systems are then assembled; the shifter, chain, and saddle system are installed; and the final assembly is completed.

caption.p: Components and corresponding modules of a bicycle
Generation of an assembly sequence for a bicycle based on CRM.

sec.p: The bicycle example shows that the components of the bicycle are grouped and assembled prior to final assembly. Using the inference procedure of this research, the association analysis of the whole bicycle can be completed. Figure 9 shows the hierarchical assembly procedure, including the subassembly extraction.

caption.p: Generation of an assembly sequence for a bicycle based on MCRR.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Computer-aided design is widely used for the element analysis, functional simulation, and prototyping electrical systems. However, a good design is evaluated on its ability not only to meet customer requirements but also to produce the product inexpensively, effectively, and in a way that eases its manufacture. Designers always focus on the analysis of customer requirements and the product’s function, structure, and material but often overlook assembly constraints in the design process. There are many ways to verify a design using solid modeling and finite element methods. However, these are technology-intensive and time-consuming methods. The MCRR approach provides an efficient and feasible method to assist the designer to review, combine, and modify some unreasonable or inefficient components when choosing design alternatives and assembly processes.

Modular design is a trend in product design because it is beneficial not only for global design and manufacturing but also for aftermarket service. The MCRR method uses subassembly extraction rules to reduce the complexity of the assembly process and applies the contact relation reasoning process to generate a feasible assembly procedure. The assembly sequence of the coffeemaker is generated using a matrix-operation approach. The MCRR method can produce possible parts, modules, and whole assemblies even when the components of the design alternatives are as large as a car or airplane. The parts are assigned to nodes and connected with liaison lines based on the assembly contact relations. The connection relations can be simplified using the three proposed steps that are shown to be beneficial in reducing the effort of assembly generation, especially in modular product design.

The proposed method could also be used in the automobile or aerospace industries. Not only is the assembly reasoning method easily applied to these industries but also the savings would be significant. Other advantages include the facilitation of modular design processes and communication between global design teams. One of the typical examples is aero-engine assembly. There are seven basic modules: fan or low-pressure compressor, high-pressure compressor, combustion chamber, high-pressure turbine, low-pressure turbine, exhaust nozzle, and control system. It is difficult to determine the full engine assembly sequences until all components arrive to the assembly line. Practically and actually, the modules are designed, manufactured, and assembled in different places. The effectiveness of the “design, manufacture and assembly split” within the different companies or countries depends on the capability of the system integrator understands how to decompose the system and then on the basis of how such decomposition is integrated. It is noted that MCRR provides a feasible approach and assistant sequences generation approach from subassembly to final assembly.

Further research will be devoted to the determination of the most suitable assembly operation for each assembly sequence generated by the MCRR approach. By studying the operation time and cost of each possible assembly type and step, the total operation time and cost of the corresponding assembly can be determined, respectively. The efficiency of the assembly of design alternatives can be evaluated by total assembly time and the relevant cost. Designers can then compare the efficiency and cost of a modified design to the original design.

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Ming-Chyuan Lin is currently a professor in the Department of Creative Product Design at Nanhua University, Taiwan. He is also an adjunct professor in the Department of Industrial Design at National Cheng Kung University, Taiwan. He received his BSE in Industrial Design from National Cheng Kung University and MS and PhD in Industrial Engineering from the University of Missouri-Columbia, USA. His research interests are human factors engineering, intelligent property creativity and management, and product design and computer-integrated design and manufacturing systems.

Chen-Cheng Lin is currently an assistant professor in the Department of Creative Product Design at Nanhua University, Taiwan. He received his PhD in Technology Application and Human Resource Development from the National Taiwan Normal University, Taiwan. His research interests are technological literacy, form creativity, and arts design.

Yuan-Yeuan Tai is currently a senior manager in the Aerospace Industrial Development Corporation in Taiwan. He received his BS and MS in Aeronautical and Mechanical Engineering from Tamkang University, and PhD in Industrial Design from National Cheng Kung University, Taiwan. His research interests are computer-aided design, manufacturing systems, product data management, and design system development.

Ming-Shi Chen is currently an assistant professor in the Department of Product Design at Transworld University in Taiwan, ROC. He received his MS and PhD in Industrial Design from National Cheng Kung University, Taiwan. His research interests are computer-aided design, technical issues for e-commerce, multimedia design for web page, product design, and ergonomics.

Ching-Chi Tseng is currently a PhD candidate in the Department of Industrial Design at National Cheng Kung University, Taiwan. He is also a senior lecturer in the Department of Interior Space Design at National Feng-Shan Senior Commercial & Industrial Vocational School in Taiwan. His research interests are product design, ergonomics, interior space design, bike clothing design, symbol design, and corporate identity system.
